extendedIngredients.name: french bread
extendedIngredients.original: 6 ounces sourdough or French bread, torn into 6 (1-ounce) pieces
extendedIngredients.originalName: ounces sourdough or French bread, torn into 6 pieces

extendedIngredients.name: fresh flat-leaf parsley
extendedIngredients.original: 1 cup coarsely chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley

extendedIngredients.name: shrimp
extendedIngredients.original: 2 1/4 pounds large shrimp, peeled and deveined

title: Shrimp in Green Sauce
summary: You can never have too many main course recipes, so give Shrimp in Green Sauce a try. This recipe serves 6. One portion of this dish contains approximately 39g of protein, 11g of fat, and a total of 349 calories. For $4.5 per serving, this recipe covers 27% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. 1 person were impressed by this recipe. If you have flat-leaf parsley, green onions, wine, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the french bread you could follow this main course with the French Bread Pudding as a dessert. It is a good option if you're following a dairy free and pescatarian diet. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 45 minutes. With a spoonacular score of 66%, this dish is good. Try Shrimp with Green Sauce, Shrimp with Green Sauce, and Shrimp Enchiladas with Green Sauce for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Riesling, and Sauvignon Blanc are great choices for Shrimp. These crisp white wines work well with shrimp prepared in a variety of ways, whether grilled, fried, or in garlic sauce. The St. Michael-Eppan Anger Pinot Grigio with a 4.3 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 23 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: St. Michael-Eppan Anger Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description: Depending on the soil and microclimate, Pinot gris varies from a simple everyday wine all the way up to absolute top growths. The warm, sun-exposed vineyards of the Anger sites, with their loamy limestone gravel soils, are a textbook example. The Anger Alto Adige Pinot Grigio has a noble structure, nice balance and fine acidity â€“ making it an absolute pleasure to drink. The strong white goes well with fish and fish soup, guinea fowl breast or veal fillet.

instructions: Preheat oven to 500.                                                                                                Place olive oil and garlic in a food processor; process until garlic is finely chopped, scraping sides of bowl occasionally. Add green onions and parsley in food processor; pulse until minced. Spoon garlic mixture into a large bowl. Add 1/2 teaspoon salt, black pepper, red pepper, and shrimp to garlic mixture, and toss well to coat.                                                                                                Spoon the shrimp mixture into a shallow roasting pan, and add the wine. Bake at 500 for 7 minutes or until the shrimp are done, stirring once. Serve with bread.

steps.step: Place olive oil and garlic in a food processor; process until garlic is finely chopped, scraping sides of bowl occasionally.
Add green onions and parsley in food processor; pulse until minced. Spoon garlic mixture into a large bowl.
Add 1/2 teaspoon salt, black pepper, red pepper, and shrimp to garlic mixture, and toss well to coat.
Spoon the shrimp mixture into a shallow roasting pan, and add the wine.
Bake at 500 for 7 minutes or until the shrimp are done, stirring once.
